sections.title: Introduction
sections.content:
Biology is the scientific study of life. The scope of biology is vast—from the molecular machinery inside cells to the global interactions of ecosystems. As you explore biology, you will discover unifying themes that connect the diverse forms of life on Earth. This chapter introduces these themes and shows how biologists use scientific inquiry to understand the natural world.

## What Makes Something Alive?

All living organisms share certain characteristics that distinguish them from nonliving matter:

- **Organization**: Life is organized in a hierarchy, from molecules to cells, tissues, organs, and entire organisms.
- **Information**: Living things store and use genetic information encoded in DNA.
- **Energy and Matter**: Organisms acquire and use energy to maintain their complex organization.
- **Interactions**: Living things interact with their environment and with each other.
- **Evolution**: All life on Earth is connected through evolution—the process of change over time.

## The Central Role of DNA

DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) is the molecule that carries genetic information in all living organisms. As Campbell Biology states, genetic information is encoded in specific sequences of the four types of nucleotides—abbreviated A, T, C, and G. These geometric shapes and letters are simple symbols for the nucleotides in a small section of one strand of a DNA molecule.

Protein-encoding genes control protein production indirectly, using a related molecule called RNA as an intermediary. The sequence of nucleotides along a gene is transcribed into mRNA, which is then translated into a linked series of protein building blocks called amino acids. Once completed, the amino acid chain forms a specific protein with a unique shape and function. The entire process by which the information in a gene directs the manufacture of a cellular product is called gene expression.

## Regulation and Feedback

The key to maintaining biological organization is the ability of many biological processes to self-regulate by a mechanism called feedback. In feedback regulation, the output or product of a process regulates that very process. The most common form of regulation in living systems is negative feedback, a loop in which the response reduces the initial stimulus. As seen in the example of insulin signaling, after a meal the level of the sugar glucose in your blood rises, which stimulates cells of the pancreas to secrete insulin. Insulin, in turn, causes body cells to take up glucose and liver cells to store it, thus decreasing the blood glucose level. This eliminates the stimulus for insulin secretion, shutting off the pathway. Thus, the output of the process (insulin) negatively regulates that process.

Though less common than processes regulated by negative feedback, there are also many biological processes regulated by positive feedback, in which an end product speeds up its own production.

## How Scientists Study Life

Science is a way of understanding the natural world through observation, experimentation, and logical reasoning. The way that researchers answer questions about the natural and physical world is often idealized as the scientific method. However, very few scientific inquiries adhere rigidly to the sequence of steps that are typically used to describe this approach. For example, a scientist may start to design an experiment, but then backtrack after realizing that more preliminary observations are necessary.

Because science only deals with natural, testable explanations for natural phenomena, it can neither support nor contradict supernatural explanations. Science and religion are not mutually exclusive or contradictory; they are simply concerned with different issues.

## An Example: Mouse Coat Color

Consider beach mice and inland mice—members of the same species (Peromyscus polionotus) but with different fur colors. Beach mice live on sparsely vegetated sand dunes along the coast. The light tan, dappled fur on their backs causes them to blend into their surroundings, providing camouflage. Members of the same species living about 30 km inland have dark fur on their backs, camouflaging them against the dark ground of their habitat. Scientists have studied this difference to understand how natural selection shapes populations. The researchers built hundreds of models of mice and spray-painted them to resemble either beach or inland mice, leaving coloration as the only factor that could account for the low predation rate on models camouflaged with respect to the surrounding environment.

sections.title: Concept 1.1: The Study of Life Reveals Unifying Themes
sections.content:
Biology is a subject of enormous scope. Consider a few examples: A single-celled bacterium, a ginkgo tree, and a humpback whale are all alive, yet they are very different. How do we know they are all alive? What do they have in common? As we explore biology, we will discover unifying themes that connect the diverse forms of life on Earth.

## Theme 1: Organization

Life can be studied at different levels of biological organization, from molecules to the entire living planet. This hierarchy of biological organization extends from the biosphere—all the environments on Earth that support life—down to molecules, which are clusters of atoms held together by chemical bonds.

At each level of the biological hierarchy, we find a correlation between structure and function. For example, the structure of a bird's wing is adapted for flight, and the structure of a neuron is adapted for transmitting nerve impulses. Analyzing a biological structure gives us clues about what it does and how it works.

## Theme 2: Information

Within cells, structures called chromosomes contain genetic material in the form of DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid). Genetic information is encoded in specific sequences of the four types of nucleotides—abbreviated A, T, C, and G. The entire "library" of genetic instructions that an organism inherits is called its genome.

Protein-encoding genes control protein production indirectly, using a related molecule called RNA as an intermediary. The sequence of nucleotides along a gene is transcribed into mRNA, which is then translated into a linked series of protein building blocks called amino acids. Once completed, the amino acid chain forms a specific protein with a unique shape and function. The entire process by which the information in a gene directs the manufacture of a cellular product is called gene expression.

## Theme 3: Energy and Matter

Life requires energy. The input of energy, primarily from the sun, and the transformation of energy from one form to another make life possible. When you eat food, your body breaks down the organic molecules in the food, releasing energy stored in the chemical bonds. This energy powers your body's activities.

Organisms are open systems that interact continuously with their environments. Both energy and matter are transferred between organisms and their surroundings. For example, plants absorb light energy from the sun and take up water and minerals from the soil. They also release oxygen into the air and take in carbon dioxide.

## Theme 4: Interactions

Interactions are important not only within organisms but also between organisms. Each organism interacts continuously with its environment, which includes other organisms as well as nonliving factors. The roots of a tree, for instance, interact with soil fungi in a mutually beneficial association. The tree provides the fungi with sugars, while the fungi help the tree absorb water and minerals from the soil.

## Theme 5: Evolution

Evolution is the process of change that has transformed life on Earth from its earliest beginnings to the vast array of organisms living today. Evolution accounts for life's unity and diversity. The many kinds of beetles, the wide variety of songbirds, and the diversity of fishes are all products of evolution. Evolution is the core theme of biology—a theme that will help explain both the unity and diversity of life.

sections.title: Concept 1.2: The Core Theme: Evolution Accounts for the Unity and Diversity of Life
sections.content:
Evolution is the process of change that has transformed life on Earth from its earliest beginnings to the vast array of organisms living today. Evolution is the core theme of biology—a theme that will help explain both the unity and diversity of life.

## Evolution: The Unifying Principle of Biology

Evolution makes sense of everything we know about living organisms. Organisms living on Earth today are modified descendants of common ancestors. Just as you have a family tree that traces your ancestry back through many generations, all of life can be viewed as a family tree extending back through time. This tree of life is called a phylogeny.

## Unity in the Diversity of Life

As diverse as life is, there is also evidence of remarkable unity. For example, the universal genetic language of DNA unites all forms of life. This common genetic language is evidence that all life is related. The unity of life is also evident in many features of cell structure. For example, all cells are enclosed by a membrane that regulates the passage of materials between the cell and its surroundings.

## Diversity Through Evolution

How does evolution account for both the unity and diversity of life? The answer lies in descent with modification. As populations of organisms adapted to different environments over millions of years, they accumulated diverse modifications, or adaptations, that fit them to specific ways of life. Yet, even as lineages have diverged, they have retained fundamental similarities inherited from their common ancestors.

## Classifying the Diversity of Life

To make sense of the diversity of life, biologists classify organisms into groups. The largest, most inclusive group is a domain. There are three domains: Bacteria, Archaea, and Eukarya. The first two domains, Bacteria and Archaea, consist of prokaryotes—organisms whose cells lack a nucleus. The third domain, Eukarya, includes all eukaryotes—organisms whose cells contain a nucleus.

The domain Eukarya includes three smaller groups called kingdoms: Plantae (plants), Fungi (fungi), and Animalia (animals). These kingdoms consist mostly of multicellular eukaryotes. The domain Eukarya also includes various groups of mostly unicellular eukaryotes, collectively called protists.

## Charles Darwin and the Theory of Natural Selection

In 1859, Charles Darwin published On the Origin of Species by Means of Natural Selection. Darwin's book articulated two main points. First, contemporary species arose from a succession of ancestors that differed from them. Darwin called this evolutionary change "descent with modification." Second, he proposed a mechanism for descent with modification: natural selection.

Darwin's theory of evolution by natural selection can be summarized as follows:

1. **Variation exists** in any population of organisms.
2. **Some variations are heritable**—they can be passed from parents to offspring.
3. **More offspring are produced** than can survive and reproduce.
4. **Individuals with heritable traits** that are best suited to their environment are more likely to survive and reproduce.
5. **Over time**, favorable traits accumulate in the population.

Natural selection is a process in which individuals that have certain inherited traits tend to survive and reproduce at higher rates than other individuals because of those traits. In this way, natural selection can cause evolution to occur—an evolutionary change in which the genetic composition of a population changes over time.

## The Tree of Life

Biologists often represent evolutionary relationships in the form of a branching diagram called a phylogenetic tree. Like a family tree, a phylogenetic tree represents patterns of descent, not phenotypic similarity. The branches of a phylogenetic tree can be rotated around a branch point without changing the information the tree conveys.

All of life is connected through evolution. The tree of life shows that all organisms share a common ancestor. As we trace the tree of life backward in time, the branches converge, ultimately connecting all life to a single common ancestor that lived billions of years ago.

sections.title: Concept 1.3: In Studying Nature, Scientists Form and Test Hypotheses
sections.content:
Our innate curiosity often stimulates us to pose questions about the natural basis for the phenomena we observe in the world. What caused the different chimpanzee behaviors observed in the wild? What explains the variation in coat color among the mice of a single species? Answering such questions usually involves forming and testing logical explanations—that is, hypotheses.

## Exploration and Observation

Scientific inquiry begins with observations about the natural world. Observations can be made with the unaided eye or with tools such as microscopes, telescopes, or sensors that extend our senses. Recorded observations are called data. Data can be qualitative (descriptions rather than measurements) or quantitative (recorded measurements, which are sometimes organized into tables and graphs).

## Gathering and Analyzing Data

Scientists use a variety of tools to gather and analyze data. Technology, such as microscopes, DNA sequencers, and computers, has greatly expanded our ability to observe and measure. Scientists analyze their data using statistical tests to determine whether the results are significant—that is, whether the results are likely due to chance or to a real effect.

## Forming and Testing Hypotheses

In science, a hypothesis is an explanation, based on observations and assumptions, that leads to a testable prediction. A hypothesis must be testable and falsifiable—that is, there must be some way to check whether it is false. A hypothesis can be supported or rejected, but it can never be proven true beyond all doubt.

Once a hypothesis is formed, scientists make predictions—logical consequences of the hypothesis. For example, if a hypothesis states that a certain nutrient increases plant growth, a prediction might be that plants given this nutrient will grow taller than plants not given the nutrient.

Scientists test hypotheses by carrying out experiments or by making further observations. In an experiment, scientists typically test the effect of one variable by comparing an experimental group with a control group. Ideally, the experimental and control groups differ only in the one factor the experiment is designed to test.

## The Flexibility of the Scientific Process

The way that researchers answer questions about the natural and physical world is often idealized as the scientific method. However, very few scientific inquiries adhere rigidly to the sequence of steps that are typically used to describe this approach. For example, a scientist may start to design an experiment, but then backtrack after realizing that more preliminary observations are necessary.

Scientific inquiry is an iterative process—scientists often repeat steps, revise their hypotheses, and design new experiments based on what they learn. The process is flexible and creative, not a rigid set of rules.

## A Case Study in Scientific Inquiry: Investigating Coat Coloration in Mouse Populations

To illustrate scientific inquiry in action, consider research on coat coloration in mouse populations. Beach mice (Peromyscus polionotus) living on sparsely vegetated sand dunes along the coast have light tan, dappled fur that helps them blend into their surroundings. Members of the same species living about 30 km inland have dark fur that matches their darker habitat.

Scientists hypothesized that natural selection favors mice whose coloration matches their environment, providing camouflage from predators. To test this hypothesis, researchers built hundreds of models of mice and spray-painted them to resemble either beach or inland mice. They placed these models in both beach and inland habitats and monitored predation rates.

The results showed that models that matched their environment (light models on beaches, dark models inland) had lower predation rates than mismatched models. This supported the hypothesis that coloration provides a survival advantage through camouflage.

## Variables and Controls in Experiments

In a controlled experiment, scientists typically test the effect of one variable by comparing an experimental group with a control group. The experimental group is exposed to the variable being tested, while the control group is not. Ideally, the experimental and control groups differ only in the one factor the experiment is designed to test.

For example, in testing the effect of a fertilizer on plant growth, the experimental group would receive the fertilizer, while the control group would not. Both groups would be grown under identical conditions (same soil, water, light, temperature) except for the presence or absence of the fertilizer.

## Theories in Science

In everyday conversation, "theory" often means a hunch or a speculation. In science, however, a theory is much broader in scope than a hypothesis. A scientific theory is a comprehensive explanation of some aspect of nature that is supported by a vast body of evidence. Theories are not guesses—they are well-supported explanations that have been tested repeatedly and have not been contradicted.

For example, the theory of evolution by natural selection is supported by evidence from many fields, including genetics, paleontology, and comparative anatomy. Scientific theories can be modified or even rejected if new evidence contradicts them, but they represent our best current understanding of how nature works.

sections.title: Concept 1.4: Science Benefits from a Cooperative Approach and Diverse Viewpoints
sections.content:
Science is a social activity. Scientists build on the work of others, share their findings with the scientific community, and benefit from diverse viewpoints. This collaborative and inclusive approach strengthens scientific inquiry and leads to more robust discoveries.

## Building on the Work of Others

Science is cumulative. Scientists build on the work of previous researchers, extending and refining our understanding of the natural world. When scientists publish their research in scientific journals, they provide detailed descriptions of their methods and results, allowing other scientists to evaluate, replicate, and build upon their work.

The scientific community evaluates new findings through peer review—a process in which experts in the field review research before it is published. This process helps ensure that published research meets high standards of quality and reliability.

Scientific knowledge advances through the collective efforts of many researchers working in laboratories and field sites around the world. Major breakthroughs often result from the integration of findings from multiple studies and different fields of research.

## Science, Technology, and Society

Science and technology are closely related but distinct. Science seeks to understand the natural world through observation and experimentation. Technology applies scientific knowledge for specific purposes, such as developing new medicines, creating more efficient energy sources, or improving agricultural practices.

The relationship between science and technology is bidirectional. Scientific discoveries can lead to new technologies, and new technologies can enable new scientific discoveries. For example, the development of DNA sequencing technology has revolutionized our ability to study genetics and evolution.

Science and technology have profound impacts on society. Medical advances have extended human life expectancy. Agricultural innovations have increased food production. Communication technologies have transformed how we share information. However, scientific and technological advances also raise ethical questions that society must address.

## The Value of Diverse Viewpoints in Science

Many of the technological innovations with the most profound impact on human society originated in settlements along trade routes, where a rich mix of different cultures ignited new ideas. For example, the printing press, which helped spread knowledge to all social classes, was invented by the German Johannes Gutenberg around 1440. This invention relied on several innovations from China, including paper and ink.

Similarly, science benefits from a diversity of backgrounds and viewpoints among its practitioners. Different perspectives can lead to new questions, innovative approaches, and creative solutions to scientific problems. A diverse scientific community is better equipped to address the complex challenges facing our world.

Historically, women, people of color, and other underrepresented groups have faced significant obstacles in pursuing careers in science. Over the past 50 years, changing attitudes have increased the proportion of women in biology and some other sciences, so that now women constitute roughly half of undergraduate biology majors and biology Ph.D. students. However, progress has been slower at higher levels in the profession, and many groups are still significantly underrepresented in many branches of science and technology.

This lack of diversity hampers the progress of science. The more voices that are heard at the table, the more robust, valuable, and productive the scientific interchange will be. Science benefits when it includes the perspectives and contributions of people from all backgrounds.

title: Chapter 2: The Chemical Context of Life
description: Chapter 2 of Campbell Biology: The Chemical Context of Life

sections.title: Introduction
sections.content:
Matter consists of chemical elements in pure form and in combinations called compounds. Organisms are composed of matter, which is anything that takes up space and has mass. Matter is made up of elements, substances that cannot be broken down to other substances by chemical reactions. A compound is a substance consisting of two or more different elements combined in a fixed ratio.

Understanding the chemical context of life is essential for biology. The properties of life emerge from the properties of matter. For example, the structure of an atom determines how it interacts with other atoms, which in turn determines the structure and function of molecules, which determine the structure and function of cells, and so on up the hierarchy of biological organization.

This chapter explores the chemical foundation of life, beginning with the structure of atoms and how they combine to form molecules and compounds. We will examine how the properties of elements depend on the structure of their atoms, how chemical bonds form between atoms, and how chemical reactions make and break these bonds.

sections.title: Concept 2.1: Matter Consists of Chemical Elements in Pure Form and in Combinations Called Compounds
sections.content:
Matter is anything that takes up space and has mass. All matter, including the matter that makes up living organisms, consists of chemical elements. An element is a substance that cannot be broken down to other substances by chemical reactions. Today, chemists recognize 92 elements occurring in nature; a few more have been made in the laboratory.

## Elements and Compounds

A compound is a substance consisting of two or more different elements combined in a fixed ratio. Table salt, for example, is a compound with the chemical formula NaCl—sodium (Na) and chlorine (Cl) in a 1:1 ratio. A compound has characteristics different from those of its elements. Sodium is a metal, and chlorine is a poisonous gas. When they combine, they form an edible compound essential to many organisms.

## The Elements of Life

Of the 92 natural elements, about 20–25% are essential elements, elements that an organism needs to live a healthy life and reproduce. Just four elements—oxygen (O), carbon (C), hydrogen (H), and nitrogen (N)—make up about 96% of living matter. Calcium (Ca), phosphorus (P), potassium (K), sulfur (S), and a few other elements account for most of the remaining 4% of an organism's mass.

Some elements are required by an organism in only minute quantities; these are called trace elements. For example, iron (Fe) is a trace element required by all forms of life. In vertebrates, iron is a component of hemoglobin, the protein that transports oxygen in the blood. An iron deficiency in the diet prevents the synthesis of hemoglobin, leading to anemia.

## Case Study: Evolution of Tolerance to Toxic Elements

Some naturally occurring elements can be toxic. For example, some naturally occurring areas have high levels of the element selenium. Some plants have evolved tolerance to high selenium levels and can accumulate selenium in their tissues. When these plants die and decompose, selenium enters the soil, making it available to other plants. This case study illustrates how organisms can adapt to their chemical environment through evolution.

sections.title: Concept 2.2: An Element's Properties Depend on the Structure of Its Atoms
sections.content:
Each element consists of a certain kind of atom that is different from the atoms of other elements. An atom is the smallest unit of matter that still retains the properties of an element. Atoms are so small that it would take about a million of them to stretch across the period printed at the end of this sentence.

## Subatomic Particles

Atoms are composed of even smaller parts called subatomic particles. Relevant to biology, there are three kinds of subatomic particles: neutrons, protons, and electrons. Neutrons and protons form the atomic nucleus. The electrons form a cloud around the nucleus.

Neutrons and protons have almost identical mass, about 1.7 × 10⁻²⁴ gram. The mass of an electron is only about 1/2000 that of a neutron or proton, so electrons are not included when determining the total mass of an atom.

## Atomic Number and Atomic Mass

All atoms of a particular element have the same number of protons in their nuclei. This number of protons, which is unique to that element, is called the atomic number and is written as a subscript to the left of the symbol for the element. For example, ₂He means that an atom of helium has 2 protons in its nucleus.

The mass number is the sum of protons plus neutrons in the nucleus of an atom. The mass number is written as a superscript to the left of an element's symbol. For example, ⁴₂He means that a helium atom has 2 protons and 2 neutrons (4 - 2 = 2).

## Isotopes

All atoms of a given element have the same number of protons, but some atoms of that element may differ in the number of neutrons. Two atoms of the same element that differ in the number of neutrons are called isotopes. For example, the most common isotope of carbon is ¹²C (carbon-12), which has 6 protons and 6 neutrons. Carbon-13 (¹³C) has 6 protons and 7 neutrons. Carbon-14 (¹⁴C) has 6 protons and 8 neutrons.

Some isotopes are radioactive, meaning that their nuclei decay spontaneously, giving off particles and energy. Radioactive isotopes have many useful applications in biological research and medicine. For example, radioactive isotopes can be used as tracers to follow atoms through metabolic processes.

## Electron Shells and Chemical Bonding

The chemical behavior of an atom depends mostly on the number of electrons in its outermost shell, called the valence shell. Atoms with incomplete valence shells can interact with certain other atoms in such a way that each partner atom completes its valence shell. These interactions usually result in atoms staying close together, held by attractions called chemical bonds.

The periodic table of the elements shows the electron distribution diagrams for the first 18 elements. In each diagram, the electrons are shown as black dots and the shells are shown as concentric circles. The elements are arranged in rows, called periods, according to how many electron shells they have. The elements are also arranged in columns, called groups, according to how many electrons they have in their valence shell.

sections.title: Concept 2.3: The Formation and Function of Molecules and Ionic Compounds Depend on Chemical Bonding Between Atoms
sections.content:
Now that we have looked at the structure of atoms, we can move up the hierarchy of organization and see how atoms combine to form molecules and ionic compounds. Atoms with incomplete valence shells can interact with certain other atoms in such a way that each partner atom completes its valence shell: The atoms either share or transfer valence electrons. These interactions usually result in atoms staying close together, held by attractions called chemical bonds.

## Covalent Bonds

The strongest kinds of chemical bonds are covalent bonds in molecules and ionic bonds in dry ionic compounds. A covalent bond is the sharing of a pair of valence electrons by two atoms. For example, two hydrogen atoms, each with a single electron, can share their electrons to form a molecule of hydrogen (H₂).

In a covalent bond, the shared electrons count as part of each atom's valence shell. A molecule consists of two or more atoms held together by covalent bonds.

## Nonpolar and Polar Covalent Bonds

Atoms in a molecule attract shared electrons to varying degrees, depending on the element. The attraction of a particular kind of atom for the electrons of a covalent bond is called its electronegativity. The more electronegative an atom, the more strongly it pulls shared electrons toward itself.

In a covalent bond between two atoms of the same element, the electrons are shared equally because the two atoms have the same electronegativity—the tug-of-war is at a standoff. Such a bond is called a nonpolar covalent bond. For example, the single bond of H₂ is nonpolar, as is the double bond of O₂.

However, when an atom is bonded to a more electronegative atom, the electrons of the bond are not shared equally. This type of bond is called a polar covalent bond. Such bonds vary in their polarity, depending on the relative electronegativity of the two atoms. For example, the bonds between the oxygen and hydrogen atoms of a water molecule are quite polar. Oxygen is one of the most electronegative elements, attracting shared electrons much more strongly than hydrogen does. In a covalent bond between oxygen and hydrogen, the electrons spend more time near the oxygen nucleus than near the hydrogen nucleus.

Because electrons have a negative charge and are pulled toward oxygen in a water molecule, the oxygen atom has partial negative charges (indicated by the Greek letter δ with a minus sign, δ⁻, or "delta minus"), and the hydrogen atoms have partial positive charges (δ⁺, or "delta plus").

## Ionic Bonds

In some cases, two atoms are so unequal in their attraction for valence electrons that the more electronegative atom strips an electron completely away from its partner. The two resulting oppositely charged atoms (or molecules) are called ions. A positively charged ion is called a cation, while a negatively charged ion is called an anion.

Because of their opposite charges, cations and anions attract each other; this attraction is called an ionic bond. Note that the transfer of an electron is not, by itself, the formation of a bond; rather, it allows a bond to form because it results in two ions of opposite charge. Any two ions of opposite charge can form an ionic bond.

Compounds formed by ionic bonds are called ionic compounds, or salts. We know them as salts, such as sodium chloride (table salt, NaCl). In the dry state, salts do not consist of molecules. Instead, they are aggregates of cations and anions stacked in a crystal lattice. Each ion is surrounded by ions of the opposite charge.

## Weak Chemical Bonds

Several types of weak chemical bonds are important in organisms. For example, hydrogen bonds form when a hydrogen atom covalently bonded to one electronegative atom is also attracted to another electronegative atom. In living cells, the electronegative partners are usually oxygen or nitrogen atoms.

Van der Waals interactions are weak attractions between molecules or parts of molecules that result from transient local partial charges. Although they are individually weak, van der Waals interactions can be important when many such interactions occur simultaneously.

sections.title: Concept 2.4: Chemical Reactions Make and Break Chemical Bonds
sections.content:
Matter is conserved in chemical reactions. The same number of atoms of each element that entered a reaction are present when the reaction is complete. The starting materials in a chemical reaction are called reactants, and the end materials are called products.

## Chemical Reactions

A chemical reaction is the making and breaking of chemical bonds, leading to changes in the composition of matter. For example, we can rephrase the burning of hydrogen gas (H₂) with oxygen gas (O₂) to form water (H₂O) as a chemical reaction:

2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O

This reaction can proceed in either direction, depending on the relative concentrations of the reactants and products. The direction in which a chemical reaction proceeds is influenced by the relative concentrations of reactants and products.

## Chemical Equilibrium

Chemical reactions are reversible. The point at which the forward and reverse reactions occur at the same rate is called chemical equilibrium. At equilibrium, the relative concentrations of reactants and products no longer change with time. However, this does not mean that the reactants and products are equal in concentration, but rather that their concentrations have stabilized at a particular ratio.

It is important to note that reactions at equilibrium are not static. There is no net change in the relative concentrations of reactants and products, but the reactions are still proceeding. The reactions are simply proceeding in both directions at the same rate.

## The Importance of Chemical Reactions in Biology

All chemical reactions within an organism are collectively called metabolism. Metabolism is the totality of an organism's chemical reactions. Metabolism is an emergent property of life that arises from orderly interactions between molecules.

Chemical reactions in cells are often organized into metabolic pathways, in which each step is catalyzed by a specific enzyme. Enzymes are proteins that act as catalysts, speeding up chemical reactions without being consumed by the reaction.

title: Chapter 3: Water and Life
description: Chapter 3 of Campbell Biology: Water and Life

sections.title: Introduction
sections.content:
Water is the substance that makes life possible. All organisms are made mostly of water and live in an environment dominated by water. Water's unique properties, which emerge from its molecular structure, make it essential for life on Earth.

The polarity of water molecules results in hydrogen bonding, which gives water its remarkable properties. These properties include water's cohesive behavior, its ability to moderate temperature, its expansion upon freezing, and its versatility as a solvent. Understanding these properties helps explain why water is so important to life and how organisms have adapted to their aqueous environments.

sections.title: Concept 3.1: Polar Covalent Bonds in Water Molecules Result in Hydrogen Bonding
sections.content:
The water molecule, H₂O, is composed of two hydrogen atoms covalently bonded to an oxygen atom. The bonds between oxygen and hydrogen are polar covalent bonds. Because oxygen is more electronegative than hydrogen, the electrons of the covalent bonds spend more time closer to oxygen than to hydrogen. As a result, the oxygen atom has a partial negative charge (δ⁻), and each hydrogen atom has a partial positive charge (δ⁺).

## Hydrogen Bonds

Because water is a polar molecule, the slightly positive hydrogen of one water molecule is attracted to the slightly negative oxygen of a nearby water molecule. The two molecules are thus held together by a hydrogen bond. Each water molecule can form hydrogen bonds with up to four neighboring water molecules.

Hydrogen bonds are much weaker than covalent bonds. At any given moment, most of the water molecules in liquid water are hydrogen-bonded to their neighbors, but the hydrogen bonds are constantly breaking and re-forming. The hydrogen bonds in water are about 1/20 as strong as covalent bonds, but they are strong enough to give water its unique properties.

## The Structure of Water

The structure of a water molecule is roughly a tetrahedron, with the oxygen atom at the center and the two hydrogen atoms and two unshared electron pairs at the corners. This structure, along with the polarity of the O-H bonds, allows water molecules to form extensive networks of hydrogen bonds with each other.

sections.title: Concept 3.2: Four Emergent Properties of Water Contribute to Earth's Suitability for Life
sections.content:
Water's unique properties emerge from the hydrogen bonding between water molecules. These properties make Earth a suitable environment for life.

## Cohesion

Cohesion is the attraction between molecules of the same kind. Water molecules have strong cohesion because of hydrogen bonding. Cohesion helps transport water against gravity in plants. When water evaporates from a leaf, hydrogen bonds cause water molecules leaving the veins to tug on molecules farther down, and the upward pull is transmitted through the water-conducting cells all the way to the roots.

Adhesion, the clinging of one substance to another, also plays a role. Adhesion of water to the walls of the vessels helps counter the downward pull of gravity.

## Moderation of Temperature

Water moderates air temperature by absorbing heat from air that is warmer and releasing stored heat to air that is cooler. Water can absorb or release a relatively large amount of heat with only a slight change in its own temperature.

Water's high specific heat is the amount of heat that must be absorbed or lost for 1 g of that substance to change its temperature by 1°C. Water's specific heat is 1 cal/g/°C. This is unusually high compared to other substances. Water's high specific heat is due to hydrogen bonding. Heat must be absorbed to break hydrogen bonds, and heat is released when hydrogen bonds form.

Water's high specific heat has important biological consequences. The temperature of large bodies of water is relatively stable, which helps moderate the climate of nearby land. The high specific heat of water also helps organisms maintain relatively constant internal temperatures.

## Expansion Upon Freezing

Water is one of the few substances that are less dense as a solid than as a liquid. While other materials contract and become denser when they solidify, water expands. This unusual behavior is due to hydrogen bonding. At temperatures above 4°C, water behaves like other liquids, expanding as it warms and contracting as it cools. As the temperature falls from 4°C to 0°C, water begins to freeze because more and more of its molecules are moving too slowly to break hydrogen bonds.

When water freezes, each molecule forms a stable hydrogen bond with four neighbors in a three-dimensional crystal. The hydrogen bonds keep the molecules far enough apart to make ice about 10% less dense than liquid water. Because ice is less dense than liquid water, it floats.

The expansion of water upon freezing has important consequences for life. If ice sank, all bodies of water would eventually freeze solid, making life in them impossible. During summer, only the upper portion of the ocean would thaw. Instead, when a deep body of water cools, the floating ice insulates the liquid water below, preventing it from freezing and allowing life to exist under the frozen surface.

## Versatility as a Solvent

A solution is a liquid that is a completely homogeneous mixture of two or more substances. The dissolving agent is called the solvent, and the substance that is dissolved is called the solute. An aqueous solution is one in which water is the solvent.

Water is a versatile solvent because of the polarity of its molecules. When an ionic compound such as sodium chloride (NaCl) is placed in water, water molecules surround the individual ions, separating and shielding them from one another. The sphere of water molecules around each dissolved ion is called a hydration shell.

Water can also dissolve compounds made of nonionic polar molecules. Even large polar molecules such as proteins can dissolve in water if they have ionic and polar regions on their surface.

sections.title: Concept 3.3: Acidic and Basic Conditions Affect Living Organisms
sections.content:
Occasionally, a hydrogen atom participating in a hydrogen bond between two water molecules shifts from one molecule to the other. When this happens, the hydrogen atom leaves its electron behind, and what is actually transferred is a hydrogen ion (H⁺), a single proton with a charge of 1⁺. The water molecule that lost a proton is now a hydroxide ion (OH⁻), which has a charge of 1⁻. The water molecule with the extra proton is now a hydronium ion (H₃O⁺).

## Acids and Bases

An acid is a substance that increases the hydrogen ion (H⁺) concentration of a solution. For example, when hydrochloric acid (HCl) is added to water, hydrogen ions dissociate from chloride ions: HCl → H⁺ + Cl⁻. By donating H⁺ to the solution, HCl is an acid.

A base is a substance that reduces the hydrogen ion (H⁺) concentration of a solution. Some bases reduce H⁺ concentration directly by accepting hydrogen ions. For example, ammonia (NH₃) acts as a base when it reacts with water: NH₃ + H₂O → NH₄⁺ + OH⁻. Other bases reduce H⁺ indirectly by dissociating to form hydroxide ions, which combine with H⁺ to form water.

## The pH Scale

The pH of a solution is defined as the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration: pH = -log[H⁺]. For a neutral aqueous solution at 25°C, [H⁺] is 10⁻⁷, so pH = -log(10⁻⁷) = -(-7) = 7.

The pH scale ranges from 0 to 14. The pH of a solution declines as H⁺ concentration increases. Acidic solutions have pH values less than 7. Basic solutions have pH values greater than 7. Most biological fluids have pH values in the range of 6 to 8.

## Buffers

The internal pH of most living cells must remain close to pH 7. Buffers are substances that minimize changes in the concentrations of H⁺ and OH⁻ in a solution. They do so by accepting hydrogen ions from the solution when they are in excess and donating hydrogen ions to the solution when they have been depleted.

Most buffer solutions contain a weak acid and its corresponding base, which combine reversibly with hydrogen ions. The carbonic acid-bicarbonate system is an important buffer in human blood. Carbonic acid (H₂CO₃) can dissociate to yield a bicarbonate ion (HCO₃⁻) and a hydrogen ion (H⁺): H₂CO₃ ⇌ HCO₃⁻ + H⁺.

## Acidification: A Threat to Water Quality

Human activities such as burning fossil fuels threaten water quality. The burning of fossil fuels releases carbon dioxide (CO₂) into the atmosphere. When CO₂ dissolves in seawater, it reacts with water to form carbonic acid: CO₂ + H₂O → H₂CO₃. This process is called ocean acidification.

Ocean acidification is a threat to marine ecosystems. Many marine organisms, such as corals and mollusks, build shells and skeletons from calcium carbonate (CaCO₃). As the ocean becomes more acidic, the concentration of carbonate ions (CO₃²⁻) decreases, making it more difficult for these organisms to build and maintain their calcium carbonate structures.

The number of genomes that have been fully sequenced has exploded, generating reams of data and prompting development of bioinformatics, the use of com - puter software and other computational tools that can handle and analyze these large data sets. The reverberations of these developments have trans - formed the study of biology and related fields. Biologists often look at problems by analyzing large sets of genes or even comparing whole genomes of different species, an approach called genomics. A similar analysis of large sets of proteins, including their sequences, is called proteomics. (Protein sequences can be determined either by using bio - chemical techniques or by translating the DNA sequences that code for them.) These approaches permeate all fields of biology, some examples of which are shown in Figure 5.26. . Taken together, genomics and proteomics have advanced our understanding of biology across many different fields. A major aim of evolutionary biology is to understand the relationships among species, both living and extinct. For example, genome sequence comparisons have identified the hippopotamus as the land mammal sharing the most recent common ancestor with whales. (See Figure 22.20.) Most plant species exist in a mutually beneficial partnership with fungi (right) and bacteria associated with the plants’ roots; these interactions improve plant growth. Genome sequencing and analysis of gene expression have allowed characterization of plant-associated communities. Such studies will help advance our understanding of such interactions and may improve agricultural practices. (See the Chapter 31 Scientific Skills Exercise and Figure 37.10.) Identifying the genetic basis for human diseases like cancer helps researchers focus their search for potential future treatments. Currently, sequencing the sets of genes expressed in an individual’s tumor can allow a more targeted approach to treating the cancer, a type of “personalized medicine.” (See Figures 12.20 and 18.27.) New DNA sequencing techniques have allowed decoding of minute quantities of DNA found in ancient tissues from our extinct relatives, the Neanderthals (Homo neanderthalensis). Sequencing the Neanderthal genome has informed our understanding of their physical appearance (as in this reconstruction), as well as their relationship with modern humans. (See Figures 34.51 and 34.52.) The tools of molecular genetics and genomics are increasingly used by forensic ecologists to identify which species of animals and plants are killed illegally. In one case, genomic sequences of DNA from illegal shipments of elephant tusks were used to track down poachers and pinpoint the territory where they were operating. (See Figure 56.8.)
